data.title: 3 Books Every U2 Fan Should Read
data.meta_description: From a visual retrospective to a revealing autobiography, here are three U2 books that every music fan should have on their reading lists.
data.text:
In the decades since their formation in 1976, Irish rock band U2 has become one of the genre’s most influential acts. The record-breaking group evolved from a brash, punk-centered sound to a polished, bold soundscape, often infused with timely commentary on social issues.

[RELATED: Top 6 U2 Albums Ranked]

Videos by American Songwriter

Lead vocalist Bono, guitarist The Edge, bassist Adam Clayton, and drummer Larry Mullen Jr. have become household names to many music fans. We’ve gathered a short list of releases that offer new insight into each member’s life and their shared journey into rock and roll history. Here are three U2 books that every music fan should have on their reading lists.

1. Surrender: 40 Songs, One Story

Bono opens up about his incredible journey from a quiet life in Ireland to one of modern music’s most recognizable frontmen in this 2021 release. Surrender: 40 Songs, One Story is a revealing look at the man behind the music, documented through chapters thoughtfully titled after some of U2’s best tracks.

2. U2: Revolution: A Complete Illustrated History

Author Mat Snow compiles the band’s first career retrospective brought to life through photographs in this visually intriguing 2019 book. Fans can transport back in time by flipping through more than 200 snapshots from each era of U2’s lengthy career. If you need an easy and informative read, U2: Revolution: A Complete Illustrated History won’t disappoint.

3. U2 by U2

Released in 2009, the fittingly titled U2 by U2 serves as the band’s first official biography, authored by Neil McCormick. Each member offers their own perspectives, insights, and memories in this informative and intricately detailed group account. Any longtime U2 fan will appreciate the bits of wisdom and personal recollections found in U2 by U2. From their creative disagreements to personal doubts, this stellar autobiography wipes away the gloss of fame.
